content: The Act may be cited as the "Filipino Veterans of World War II Congressional Gold Medal Act of 2015". The First Philippine Republic was established after the Spanish-American War, with Filipinos declaring independence on June 12, 1898. The Treaty of Paris ignored this declaration, leading to the Philippine-American War from 1899 to 1902, resulting in the establishment of the United States civil government in the Philippines. In 1934, the Philippine Independence Act established a timetable for ending colonial rule of the United States in the Philippines. President Manuel Quezon signed the National Defense Act in 1935, creating an independent army. In 1941, President Roosevelt called the Philippine army into service of the United States as tensions with Japan rose in the Pacific. The United States Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) was established, with Manila designated as the command center. The United States Forces in the Far East (USAFFE) was established, with Manila designated as the command headquarters. General Douglas MacArthur planned to absorb the entire Philippine army into the USAFFE in phases, starting with 25,000 men and 4,000 officers. Filipinos who served in the USAFFE included the Philippine Scouts, the Philippine Commonwealth Army, the new Philippine Scouts, and Filipino civilians who volunteered to serve with the United States Army. Filipino civilians who volunteered to serve in the United States Armed Forces in 1945 and 1946, and the "Guerrilla Services" who had fought behind enemy lines throughout the war, continued their wartime service until the end of 1946. The Japanese Imperial forces attacked bases of the United States Army in the Philippines shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941. After the fall of the Bataan Peninsula, over 78,000 members of the United States Armed Forces were captured, including 66,000 Filipinos and 12,000 US service members. They were transferred to Camp O'Donnell in the infamous Bataan Death March, where nearly 700 US soldiers and 6,000 to 10,000 Filipinos died. The Japanese then targeted Corregidor, defended by 13,000 US and Filipino troops. After the fall of the Bataan Peninsula, 78,000 members of the US Armed Forces and Filipino troops were captured. 800 were killed, 1,000 wounded, and 11,000 forced to march through Manila. Some troops escaped to join guerrilla armies that raided Japanese camps, sabotaged troops, and achieved victories despite being outnumbered. During the Japanese occupation, an estimated 300,000 Filipinos continued to resist Japanese forces. The guerrillas played a crucial role in restoring communication with US forces in the Pacific, providing valuable information to General MacArthur's headquarters. They even captured and transmitted Japanese naval plans for the Central Pacific. During the Japanese occupation, Filipino guerrillas provided intelligence on naval plans for the Central Pacific, aiding Allied attacks on Japanese supply lines. President Roosevelt signed laws allowing Filipinos to enlist in the US Armed Forces and promising simplified naturalization for those who served. During World War II, Filipino guerrillas aided Allied attacks on Japanese supply lines. President Roosevelt allowed Filipinos to enlist in the US Armed Forces. 16,000 Filipinos in California alone decided to enlist. The First and Second Filipino Infantry Regiments were activated in California, with nearly 9,000 Filipinos and Filipino Americans fighting in these regiments. They participated in combat in New Guinea, Leyte, Samar, Luzon, and the Southern Philippines. During World War II, Filipino guerrillas aided Allied attacks on Japanese supply lines. 800 men from the 1st and 2nd Regiments were trained in Australia for intelligence gathering, sabotage, and demolition. They coordinated with major guerrilla armies in the Philippines and assisted in freeing Allied prisoners from the Cabanatuan death camp. Philippine guerrillas provided crucial information for the liberation efforts in 1945. During World War II, Filipino guerrillas aided Allied attacks on Japanese supply lines and assisted in freeing Allied prisoners. In March 1944, members of the 2nd Filipino Infantry Regiment were reorganized as the 2nd Filipino Infantry Battalion for special assignments, including intelligence missions. Filipinos participated in the war out of national pride and commitment to the Allied forces' struggle against fascism, with 57,000 Filipinos in uniform dying in the war effort. Estimates of civilian deaths range from 700,000 to upwards of 1,000,000. During World War II, Filipino guerrillas aided Allied attacks on Japanese supply lines and assisted in freeing Allied prisoners. The prewar population of 16,000,000 included Filipinos who served in the Commonwealth Army of the Philippines, entitled to veterans benefits but later denied by the Rescission Acts of 1946. Filipino Veterans of World War II fought valiantly, with many sacrificing their lives. During World War II, Filipino veterans fought alongside the United States Armed Forces, defending and liberating sovereign territory held by the US Government. The Philippines, a US territory during the war, had Filipinos who served in the Commonwealth Army and were later denied veterans benefits by the Rescission Acts of 1946. The Filipino Veterans of World War II displayed bravery, valor, and dedication, showcasing uncommon patriotism and honor. The United States is forever indebted to their commitment and sacrifice. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The term "Filipino Veterans of World War II" includes individuals who served honorably between July 26, 1941, and December 31, 1946, under the command of the United States Armed Forces in the Far East. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The President pro tempore of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives will arrange for the award of a gold medal to Filipino Veterans of World War II. The Secretary will design and strike the Gold Medal with suitable emblems. The gold medal will be given to the Smithsonian Institution for display and research. The Smithsonian Institution should make the gold medal available for display at locations associated with Filipino Veterans of World War II. The Secretary may strike and sell duplicates in bronze to cover costs, with proceeds going to the United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 5. STATUS OF MEDALS. Medals struck under this Act are national medals for purposes of chapter 51 of title 31, United States Code and considered numismatic items under section 5134 of title 31, United States Code.
